break.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: if you break something, you make it separate into two or more pieces, for example by hitting it, dropping it, or bending it
break.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: I had to break a window to get into the house.
Don’t lean on the fence like that – you’ll break it!
Break the chocolate into small pieces and melt it over a gentle heat.
He broke the biscuit in half and handed one piece to me.
break.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if something breaks, it separates into two or more pieces
break.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: He kept pulling at the rope until it broke.
The frames are made of plastic and they tend to break quite easily.
break.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to damage a bone in your body by making it crack or split
break.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: She fell downstairs and broke her hip.
break.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to damage a machine so that it does not work properly
break.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Don’t mess about with my camera – you’ll break it.
break.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: if a machine breaks, it stops working properly
break.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: to disobey a rule or law
break.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: They’re breaking the law by employing such young children.
If you break the rules, you will be punished.
The cameras catch motorists who break the speed limit.
break.translation[0].definitions[6].defi: to not do something that you have promised to do or signed an agreement to do
break.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: You betrayed me. You broke your word.
He was worried that he might be breaking his contract.
break.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: to stop for a short time in order to have a rest or eat something
break.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: Shall we break for lunch now?
break.translation[0].definitions[8].exam: We need to break the cycle of poverty and crime in the inner cities.
We took turns driving, in order to try and break the monotony.
New talks will begin on Monday in an effort to break the deadlock.
break.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: to make someone feel that they have been completely defeated and they cannot continue working or living
break.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: Losing his business nearly broke him.
I won’t give in. I won’t be broken by him.
break.translation[0].definitions[10].def: to damage an organization so badly that it no longer has any power
break.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: The government succeeded in breaking the unions.
break.translation[0].definitions[11].def: when the day or the dawn breaks, the sky gets light
break.translation[0].definitions[11].exa: Dawn was breaking by the time we arrived home.
break.translation[0].definitions[12].def: if a storm breaks, it begins
break.translation[0].definitions[12].exa: We were keen to get back to the hotel before the storm broke.
break.translation[0].definitions[13].def: if the weather breaks, it suddenly changes and becomes cold or wet
break.translation[0].definitions[13].exa: The following day the weather broke and we had ten days of solid rain.
break.translation[0].definitions[14].def: when waves break, they fall onto the land at the edge of the water
break.translation[0].definitions[14].exa: We sat and watched the waves breaking on the shore.
break.translation[0].definitions[15].def: when a boy’s voice breaks, it becomes lower and starts to sound like a man’s voice
break.translation[0].definitions[15].exa: He was fifteen, and his voice was just beginning to break.
break.translation[0].definitions[16].def: if your voice breaks, it does not sound smooth because you are feeling strong emotions
break.translation[0].definitions[16].exa: Her voice broke as she told us what had happened.
break.translation[0].definitions[17].def: if news about an important event breaks, it becomes known
break.translation[0].definitions[17].exa: News of his resignation broke yesterday.
The minister has refused to give any interviews since the scandal broke.
break.translation[0].definitions[18].def: if you break unpleasant news to someone, you tell it to them
break.translation[0].definitions[18].exa: I didn’t know how I was going to break the news to my mother.
The doctor finally broke it to me that there was no cure.
break.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 5: to not do something that you have promised to do or signed an agreement to do
break.translation[0].note_box[0].section: I’ll never forgive him for breaking his promise to me.
I’ve promised to do it and I never break my word.
He accused her of breaking her marriage vows.
In the end she decided to break their engagement.
He took the company to court for breaking the contract.
This action broke the international agreement of 1925.
break.translation[0].note_box[1].items[0: Break belongs to a group of verbs where the same noun can be the subject of the verb or its object
break.translation[0].note_box[1].items[1: In this sentence, ‘a glass’ is the object of break
break.translation[0].note_box[1].items[2: In this sentence, ‘a glass’ is the subject of break
break.translation[0].note_box[2].section: to break something
to damage something and make it separate into pieces, for example by dropping it or hitting it
Careful you don’t break the chair.
He broke his leg.
smash
to break something with a lot of force
A policeman smashed his camera.
snap
to break something into two pieces, making a loud noise – used especially about long thin objects
He snapped the sticks in two.
to separate something into two pieces along a straight line
Using a sharp knife, split the melon in half.
fracture
to damage a bone, especially so that a line appears on the surface
I fell over and fractured my wrist.
tear
to damage paper or cloth by pulling it so that it separates into pieces
She tore up the letter and put it in the bin.
I tore my jacket.
to become broken
to become damaged and separate into pieces
Plastic breaks quite easily.
smash
to break after being hit with a lot of force
The bowl smashed as it hit the floor.
shatter
to break into a lot of small pieces
The glass shattered all over the pavement.
crack
if something cracks, a line appears on the surface, which means that it could later break into separate pieces
The ice was starting to crack.
burst
if a tyre, balloon, pipe etc bursts, it gets a hole and air or liquid suddenly comes out of it
She blew up the balloon until it burst.
to break in a straight line
The damp had caused the wood to split.
crumble
to break into a powder or a lot of small pieces
The cork just crumbled in my hand.
break.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a period of time when you stop working in order to rest, eat etc
break.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: We’ll have a short break for lunch, then start again at two o'clock.
We’d worked for ten hours without a break.
I’ll go shopping during my lunch break.
break.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: a period of time when you stop doing something before you start again
break.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: She decided to take a career break when she had children.
I wanted a break from university life.
a welcome break in my normal routine
break.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: I was beginning to feel that I needed a break.
We flew off for a week’s break in Spain.
They’re offering weekend breaks in Paris for only £100.
Are you looking forward to the summer break?
break.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: the time during the school day when classes stop and teachers and students can rest, eat, play etc
break.translation[1].definitions[3].exam: They get together with their friends at break time.
I’ll speak to you at break.
break.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: a pause for advertisements during a television or radio programme
break.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: Join us again after the break.
We’ll be back with more after a short break.
break.translation[1].definitions[5].defi: a period of time when something stops happening before it starts again
break.translation[1].definitions[5].exam: There was no sign of a break in the weather (=an improvement in bad weather).
We’ll go for a walk if there’s a break in the rain.
Latecomers will be admitted at a suitable break in the performance.
She waited for a break in the conversation.
break.translation[1].definitions[6].defi: a time when you leave a person or group, or end a relationship with someone
break.translation[1].definitions[6].exam: I wanted a clean break so that I could restart my life.
It was years before I plucked up enough courage to make the break and leave him.
He was beginning to regret his break with the Labour Party.
break.translation[1].definitions[7].defi: a space or hole in something
break.translation[1].definitions[7].exam: We crawled through a break in the hedge.
The sun shone through a break in the clouds.
break.translation[1].definitions[8].defi: a sudden or unexpected chance to do something that allows you to become successful in your job
break.translation[1].definitions[8].exam: There are hundreds of young musicians out there looking for their first break.
He got his first big break in 1998.
break.translation[1].definitions[9].defi: the place where a bone in your body has broken
break.translation[1].definitions[9].exam: It’s quite a bad break, which will take several months to heal.
break.translation[1].definitions[10].def: a situation in a game of tennis in which you win a game when your opponent is starting the game by hitting the ball first
break.translation[1].definitions[10].exa: She really needs a break of serve now if she wants to win this match.
break.translation[1].definitions[11].def: the number of points that a player wins when it is their turn to hit the ball in a game such as snooker
break.translation[1].note_box[0].section: After two hours, she took a break and switched on the radio.
I’m sorry, I can’t do any more - I need a break.
Shall we have a quick five-minute break?
I don’t usually have time for a morning break.
Everyone’s looking forward to a well-earned break when the exams are over.
break.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: if someone breaks a law, rule, agreement etc, they do not do what it says they should do
break.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: If you copy music files from the Internet, you could easily be breaking the law.
The other company broke the terms of its agreement.
break.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: if employers break a STRIKE, they force the strikers to end it, perhaps with the help of the army or the police
break.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: He broke the ambulancemen’s strike by getting the army to answer emergency calls.
break.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: to neither make a profit nor lose money
break.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: The company needs to charge $13 a ton to break even.
The retailer warns that it expects sales to be down by 15%, and it may only break even.
break.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: a period of time when you stop working or stop what you are doing in order to rest, eat, take a holiday etc
break.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: He was entitled to a forty-five minute lunch break.
Employers must provide people who work at computers with rest breaks.
break.translation[3].definitions[1].defi: a pause for advertisements during a television or radio programme
break.translation[3].definitions[1].exam: We’ll be back with more music after the break.
break.translation[3].definitions[2].defi: a sudden, large fall in market prices, especially the price of shares on a stockmarket
break.translation[3].definitions[2].exam: The big break in cattle prices has forced ranchers to stop selling young cattle.
break.translation[3].definitions[3].defi: a sudden or unexpected chance to do something, especially to be successful in your job
break.translation[3].definitions[3].exam: She got her first break in 1951 on Broadway.
He did small commercials for Yellow Pages before getting his big break with the Porsche advert.
break.translation[3].definitions[4].defi: a period of several weeks or years during which something stops, before continuing again
break.translation[3].definitions[4].exam: If you have a break in paid employment for two complete consecutive tax years, you must pay full-rate contributions when you return to work.
